item.title: HTTP
item.description: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is the way most of the web communicates. Itâ€™s the system that governs how your computer talks to servers around the world to retrieve webpages, talk to your online calendar, and even send messages in point of sales systems.

item.title: Linux
item.description: Info History informs some of the technical information, as such this section will include technical info about linux, and some history. This I think is the best way to talk about linux & unix since often the history informs the technical decisions.

item.title: Userspace
item.description: This is the good old operating system you know and love. This is where applications, your desktop, and %90 of computing is done. (5) The Laymanâ€™s Guide to Linux: User Space - YouTube (Covers most things at once, but I would recommend doing other sections first then come back to this video) Package managers Â§ These systems are designed to help a user manage packages (applications and services that run on an OS).

item.title: Number Systems (binary & hex)
item.description: When we count we traditionally use base 10. Base 10 gives us 10 values before we shift digits. We go from 0-9, and then we shift 1 digit left, and start from 0 in the far right column again: 0 1 2 .

item.title: Caching
item.description: A cache is basically a system where you store something you know you will need for later. Imagine you work in a bakery. If you wait until someone orders a loaf of bread to cook it, then now every person who comes into your store has to wait for you to cook the loaf before they can leave.

item.title: Compression
item.description: Storage space is valuable. Whether itâ€™s memory on someoneâ€™s computer that needs to be preserved to keep it running, or space on a drive to keep it from being full.

item.title: Encodings
item.description: Encoding just means a way to take a set of information in one format, and convert or represent it to another format. You can imagine the same concept (a boat, a sandwhich etc.

item.title: Hashing
item.description: Hashing is a process where you take some sort of input data and use a hashing algorithm map it to some sort of output data (called a hash). This output data should be deterministic, meaning for each input there should be 1 output when put through our hashing algorithm.

item.title: FOSS (Free and Open Source Software)
item.description: When developing software you have an important choice to make. Should users be able to see the source code to the program youâ€™re asking them to run? Should you be able to know the internals of whatâ€™s happening in your computer? Much of the software we used today is closed source and proprietary, meaning we donâ€™t know how it works, since we canâ€™t view the source code.
